thread.title: Private investors in shopping centre hunt
thread.title_full: Private investors in shopping centre hunt

title: Private investors in shopping centre hunt
text:
Pratt Retail Properties Pty Ltd, has sold the Croydon Central Shopping Centre, Victoria for over $40 million to Haben Property Fund.
Demand for neighbourhood and suburban shopping centres is high with close to $80 million worth of assets changing hands in the past week.
A private investor paid $37.3 million for the Kings Cross Centre in Potts Point, amid 150 expressions of interest.
Agents on the deal LJ Hooker Commercial Sydney's chief executive Warren Duncan and agent Stanley Wang, said the demand for higher yielding bricks and mortar investments had supported a strong sales campaign.
The rise of apartment living is also seeing a referral demand for food-anchored, smaller malls, that can be accessed on foot as more and more, apartments are being built with fewer car spaces.
Advertisement According to LJ Hooker Commercial, Sydney retail property purchases rose to $1.502 billion in the last financial year, an increase of about 15 per cent on the previous financial year's transactions.
In Victoria, Pratt Retail Properties Pty Ltd, sold the Croydon Central Shopping Centre for more than $40 million to Haben Property Fund, on a fully leased initial yield of 6.95 per cent.
JLL's Australian head of retail investments, Simon Rooney, who completed the Croydon sale said, shopping centres with high grocery and food retailing exposure have continued to perform well.
"Retail spending within the non-discretionary food category has grown by 4.7 per cent year on year as at May 2015, and 4.2 per cent per annum over the last five years, faster than all other major retail categories except for cafes, restaurants and take-away food (5.1 per cent per annum).
"Total neighbourhood transactions for 2015 year to date have reached $873 million across 31 transactions, already exceeding the annual long-term average of $800 million," Mr Rooney said.
"Volumes reached a record $1.9 billion in 2014 up 49 per cent from $1.3 billion in 2013. The number of neighbourhood transactions also increased very significantly in 2014, having risen to 71 transactions from 43 in 2013."
Mr Rooney said there was strong demand for assets from a widening range of institutional and private investors.
"The heavy focus on the non-discretionary based neighbourhood sector at present reflects the attractiveness of defensive assets which provide long term stable income returns and strong potential for capital growth," he said.
JLL Research shows neighbourhood yields nationally range between 6.25 per cent and 9.25 cent and a weighted average mid-point of 7.55 per cent as at the second quarter of 2015.
The research indicates that sub-regional rents showed signs of a rental recovery in the second quarter of 2015; while average CBD, neighbourhood and bulky goods rents increased further.
The average rent for neighbourhood centres is about $500 per square metre per annum.
Average regional rents remained stable this quarter. Yield compression was recorded across all monitored sub-sectors in the second quarter of 2015, to a greater degree in the neighbourhood and large format store sub-sectors.
